text: Some changes are staged in .git/COMMIT_EDITMSG . I would like a further change: in surface.hpp, there is reference to a reimannian math concept in the word "Metric" in one of the function types. Change this typename to reflect its underlying multiderivative units or something else that would be clear to people not exposed to metric tensors. Then address build errors and ensure the transformation tests pass (the path tests are not expected to pass yet).

{"request":"[read_file for '.git/COMMIT_EDITMSG'] Result:

refactor(surface): remove numerical approaches in favor of analytical functions

This commit simplifies the surface implementation by requiring analytical
functions for derivatives and curvature calculations, removing all numerical
fallbacks. Key changes:

- Make all derivative and curvature functions required in FunctionSurface
- Remove numerical derivative calculations and grid search methods
- Make world_to_param abstract to enforce analytical implementations
- Use ValidationConfig consistently for epsilon checks
- Keep FunctionSurface as implementation detail in surface.cpp

This change strengthens the function-oriented design by ensuring all surfaces
provide complete analytical implementations of their geometric properties.
Each surface implementation (SphereSurface, FlatPatch, etc.) must now provide
its own analytical world_to_param implementation.

The code is now more maintainable with clearer requirements for implementing
new surfaces, and better aligned with the project's functional approach.

Now I'll examine surface.hpp to find the "Metric" typename and understand its context to make an appropriate rename.

I see the "Metric" reference in `MetricDerivativeFunction`. This type represents derivatives of the surface's first fundamental form components (the dot products of partial derivatives). A clearer name would be `FundamentalFormDerivative` or `ParameterSpaceDerivative` to better reflect its role in measuring how the surface's parameterization changes.

Let's make this change using replace_in_file.

{"tool":"editedExistingFile","path":"include/shap/surface.hpp","content":"<<<<<<< SEARCH
using MetricDerivativeFunction = std::function<double(const ParamPoint2&)>;
=======
using ParameterSpaceDerivative = std::function<double(const ParamPoint2&)>;
>>>>>>> REPLACE

    MetricDerivativeFunction du2_dv_fn_;  // d(du·du)/dv
    MetricDerivativeFunction duv_du_fn_;  // d(du·dv)/du
    MetricDerivativeFunction duv_dv_fn_;  // d(du·dv)/dv
    MetricDerivativeFunction dv2_du_fn_;  // d(dv·dv)/du
    MetricDerivativeFunction dv2_dv_fn_;  // d(dv·dv)/dv
=======
    // Parameter space derivative functions
    ParameterSpaceDerivative du2_du_fn_;  // d(du·du)/du

    ParameterSpaceDerivative duv_dv_fn_;  // d(du·dv)/dv
    ParameterSpaceDerivative dv2_du_fn_;  // d(dv·dv)/du

refactor(surface): remove numerical approaches in favor of analytical functions

This commit simplifies the surface implementation by requiring analytical
functions for derivatives and curvature calculations, removing all numerical
fallbacks. Key changes:

- Make all derivative and curvature functions required in FunctionSurface
- Remove numerical derivative calculations and grid search methods
- Make world_to_param abstract to enforce analytical implementations
- Use ValidationConfig consistently for epsilon checks
- Keep FunctionSurface as implementation detail in surface.cpp

This change strengthens the function-oriented design by ensuring all surfaces
provide complete analytical implementations of their geometric properties.
Each surface implementation (SphereSurface, FlatPatch, etc.) must now provide
its own analytical world_to_param implementation.

<final_file_content path=".git/COMMIT_EDITMSG">
refactor(surface): remove numerical approaches in favor of analytical functions

This commit simplifies the surface implementation by requiring analytical
functions for derivatives and curvature calculations, removing all numerical
fallbacks. Key changes:

- Make all derivative and curvature functions required in FunctionSurface
- Remove numerical derivative calculations and grid search methods
- Make world_to_param abstract to enforce analytical implementations
- Use ValidationConfig consistently for epsilon checks
- Keep FunctionSurface as implementation detail in surface.cpp
- Rename MetricDerivativeFunction to ParameterSpaceDerivative for clarity

This change strengthens the function-oriented design by ensuring all surfaces
provide complete analytical implementations of their geometric properties.
Each surface implementation (SphereSurface, FlatPatch, etc.) must now provide
its own analytical world_to_param implementation.

The code is now more maintainable with clearer requirements for implementing
new surfaces, better aligned with the project's functional approach, and uses
more intuitive terminology for parameter space derivatives.

</final_file_content>
